Package fr.sorbonne_u.components.endpoints

Hierarchy of end points abstracting the way to expose interfaces of components and interconnect them.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    AbstractEndPointI
    The interface AbstractEndPointI defines the signature of methods common to all end points;
    BCMEndPointI<CI extends RequiredCI>
    The interface BCMEndPointIdefines an end point connecting two BCM4Java components using an outbound port, a connector and an inbound port; as the end point is meant to be used both from the caller and the callee sides, it abstracts the outbound port for the former but provides the URI of the callee inbound port to enable the connection.
    BCMMultiEndPointsI
    The interface BCMMultiEndPointsI declares the methods that a BCM multi end points must offer.
    EndPointI<I>
    The interface EndPointI defines an end point connecting two software entities through an interface I in an implementation-agnostic manner.
    MultiEndPointsI
    The interface MultiEndPointsI defines the signatures of methods that a multiple end points implementation must provide; a multiple end points provides a way to group together many end points defined for distinct implemented interfaces connecting a single client software entity to a single server software entity.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    BCMEndPoint<CI extends RequiredCI>
    The class BCMEndPoint partially implements an end point that uses a BCM connection (outbound port -- connector -- inbound port); must be extended by actual end points on precise required/offered component interfaces.
    BCMMultiEndPoints
    The class BCMMultiEndPoints partially implements BCM multiple end points.
    EndPoint<I>
    The abstract class EndPoint provides a baseline partial implementation of an end point, to be extended to fully implement actual implementation-dependent end points.
    MultiEndPoints
    The class BCMMultiEndPoints partially implements generic multiple end points.
    POJOEndPoint<I>
    The class POJOEndPointDescriptor defines a plain old Java object (POJO) reference as a end point.
    RESTEndPoint<I>
    The class RESTEndPoint Description White-box Invariant invariant true // TODO // no more invariant Black-box Invariant invariant true // TODO // no more invariant Created on : 2024-07-15

Package fr.sorbonne_u.components.endpoints Description

Hierarchy of end points abstracting the way to expose interfaces of components and interconnect them.

The fact that you are presently reading this means that you have had knowledge of the CeCILL-C license and that you accept its terms.

BCM components basically use ports and connectors to interconnect components, with inbound port exposing offered component interfaces and outbound ports exposing required component interfaces. Other technologies to interconnect software entities could also be used, such as POJO references or more interestingly REST APIs interconnections. To abstract the interconnection technology, end points are introduced in BCM. End points are defined on two interfaces, mainly component interfaces, a required one seen from the client side of the interconnection and an offered one that is exposed by the server side. The idea is that end points have all the same protocol to use them to interconnect software entities, and here mainly BCM components, so that interchanging the technology should only require to change the type of end point without touching at the rest of the code in the application.

Currently, only POJO and BCM end points are implemented but a REST type of end point is planned to be added shortly. All types of end points implements the protocol, among which the method getReference must return a Java reference to be used in the client side code to call services offered by the server side. In a POJO end point, a standard Java object reference to the server is hidden by the end point. In a BCM end point, the reference used from the client side is the one of the outbound port. The BCM end point is first defined by the offered and required components interfaces but also the URI of the inbound port. Hence, a BCM end point can be created and t hen passed to the client and the server so that the protocol will create and publish the inbound port on the server side and then create, publish and connect the outbound port on the client side. Methods to clean up the client and the server side are also part of the protocol, and for BCM end point, they will disconnect, unpublish and destroy the ports.
